entry.title: The Case of the underpaid/overpaid Wage Type: A Analyzing Guide for Consultants
entry.content:
Introduction:  In SAP HCM Payroll, consultants often face situations where employees are unexpectedly underpaid or overpaid due to wage type discrepancies. These issues can arise from retroactive changes, incorrect master data entries, or schema misconfigurations.

This blog outlines a structured approach to analyze such cases using the RAW trace tools—Results Table, Audit Report, Wage Type Reporter—and PCR (Personal Calculation Rule) trace. For example, if wage type 7013 is missing or altered, this guide helps pinpoint whether it's due to retroactive master data changes or schema logic.

In this blog, I'll walk you through go-to process for analyzing missing wage types using the RAW & PCR Trace:

Results table(PC_PAYRESULT)

Audit Report(SE38 -> RPUAUD00)

Wage type reporter (PC00_M99_CWTR)

PCR: Personal Calculation Rule

1.) The First Step: Verifying the Master Data:

  -> Check the info type where the wage type is entered (e.g., 0014, 0015, 2010).

  -> Ensure it's valid for the payroll period.

2.) Enabling the RAW (Results table, Audit Report, Wage type reporter) Trace:

  -> Results table: check RT _ for the WT, check "In period" and  "for period" if the WT having the Retro.

  ->  Check the Audit report (SE38-> RPUAUD00) for any retro changes, previous values for the info types records

  -> Check the Wage type reporter (PC00_M99_CWTR) for Retro values and Wage type splits:

3.) Analyzing the PCR (Personal Calculation Rule) Trace:

  -> If RAW Trance not found not any deviations, check the PCR flow Trace, open the payroll log for the employee and try searching with the Wage type code (example: 7013), and check the amount where it is getting reduced and open the line for the PCR.

4.) Common Culprits: Why Wage Types Disappear based on PCR's:

   -> Incorrect Processing Class settings (e.g., 1- Evaluation, 2-Cumulation).

   -> A PCR with an ELIMI operation.

   -> The wage type is not included in the relevant schema.

   -> A decision in the schema that branches away from your wage type.

Conclusion: By following the RAW trace and PCR analysis steps, consultants can efficiently identify the root cause of wage type discrepancies and resolve them before they impact payroll accuracy. Whether it's a missing wage type due to an ELIMI operation in a PCR or a retroactive change not reflected in the results table, this guide equips you with the tools to investigate systematically.

For instance, checking SE38 → RPUAUD00 can reveal retro changes that explain unexpected payroll results. With these techniques, you can turn payroll day surprises into confident resolutions. Have you encountered a tricky wage type issue? Share your experience in the comments!

entry.title: SAP UI5 application to Export Data to spreadsheet from SAP UI5 tree table (sap.ui.table.TreeTable)
entry.content:
Introduction : 
    In this article, we are going to understand how to implement  export functionality the sap.ui.table.TreeTable table data to the excel(Spreadsheet) using  sap.ui.export.Spreadsheet library. In this application, we are going to create an SAP UI5 free style application which has sample JSON  data  that has employees and their family details for the expense share percentage of the medical insurance (taken as an example) and that has been binded to the UI table and a toggle button has been added to trigger the export or downloading the excel data.

Procedure: 
This is step by step guide to create a fiori application with SAP UI5 UI table and Export Button
Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the  Fiori Generator Freestyle - Basic template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

 

 

 

Application Folder Structure: 

 

 

Step 2 : Create a Dynamic Page , add UI Table Details and Add the sample JSON Data in controller 

  In TreeTableView.view.xml, Add this code and add the Sample JSON data model object in the onInit() in TreeTableView.Controller.js .

TreeTableView.view.xml

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.example.treeexporttoexcel.controller.TreeTableView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:table="sap.ui.table"
>
    <Page
        id="page"
        title="{i18n>title}"
    >
        <content>
            <table:TreeTable
                id="employeeTreeTable"
                selectionMode="None"
                enableColumnReordering="false"
                rows="{ 
       path : '/Employees',
       parameters :{
       arrayNames:['Employees','FamilyMembers']
       }
        }"
            >
               <table:extension>
                 <OverflowToolbar>
                        <Title text="{i18n>title}" />
                        <ToolbarSpacer />
                        <ToggleButton id="export_btn" text="{i18n>export_btn}" icon="sap-icon://excel-attachment" press="onExcelExport"/>
                    </OverflowToolbar>
               </table:extension>     
                <table:columns>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>employeeID}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{EmployeeID}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>employeeName}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{EmployeeName}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>designation}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{Designation} " />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>familyMemberName}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{MemberName}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>relation}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{Relationship}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>age}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{Age}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                    <table:Column>
                        <table:label>
                            <Text text="{i18n>expense}" />
                        </table:label>
                        <table:template>
                            <Text text="{ExpenseShare}" />
                        </table:template>
                    </table:Column>
                </table:columns>
            </table:TreeTable>
        </content>
    </Page>
</mvc:View>

TreeTable.controller.js

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/ui/model/json/JSONModel",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet"
], (Controller, JSONModel, MessageToast, Spreadsheet) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.example.treeexporttoexcel.controller.TreeTableView", {
        onInit() {
            var oView = this.getOwnerComponent();
            var oDataModel = new JSONModel();
            var aData = {
                "Employees": [
                    {
                        "EmployeeID": "E001",
                        "EmployeeName": "Ramesh",
                        "Designation": "Manager",
                        "FamilyMembers": [
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Anitha",
                                "Age": 35,
                                "Relationship": "Wife",
                                "ExpenseShare": 40
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Rohith",
                                "Age": 10,
                                "Relationship": "Son",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Ramanaiah",
                                "Age": 65,
                                "Relationship": "Father",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Kamala",
                                "Age": 60,
                                "Relationship": "Mother",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            }
                        ]
                    },
                    {
                        "EmployeeID": "E002",
                        "EmployeeName": "Sumana",
                        "Designation": "Developer",
                        "FamilyMembers": [
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Bhargav",
                                "Age": 35,
                                "Relationship": "Husband",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Prasanna",
                                "Age": 9,
                                "Relationship": "Daughter",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Ananda",
                                "Age": 58,
                                "Relationship": "Father",
                                "ExpenseShare": 40
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Srinidhi",
                                "Age": 55,
                                "Relationship": "Mother",
                                "ExpenseShare": 20
                            }
                        ]
                    },
                    {
                        "EmployeeID": "E003",
                        "EmployeeName": "Manish",
                        "Designation": "Auditor",
                        "FamilyMembers": [
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Bhumesh",
                                "Age": 58,
                                "Relationship": "Father",
                                "ExpenseShare": 60
                            },
                            {
                                "MemberName": "Rajeswari",
                                "Age": 50,
                                "Relationship": "Mother",
                                "ExpenseShare": 40
                            }
                        ]
                    }

                ]
            }

            oDataModel.setData(aData);
            oView.setModel(oDataModel);
        },
}); 
});

Step 3 : Implement the press event trigger of the Export To excel Button
   Add this logic in controller.js . "sap/ui/export/Spreadsheet" is the library should be used for excel export.
_convertTreeForExport() is a recursive function to fetch the child records converts to flat structure and pushes to the export data where this export data is passed to the settings of the excel sheet data.
TableView.controller.js

 onExcelExport() {
            var oBundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("i18n").getResourceBundle();
            var oTable = this.byId("employeeTreeTable");
            var oBinding = oTable.getBinding("rows");
            var aData = oBinding.getModel().getProperty("/Employees");
            var aExportData = this._convertTreeForExport(aData);
            var aCols = [
                {
                    label : oBundle.getText("employeeID"),
                    property :"EmployeeID"
                },
                {
                     label : oBundle.getText("employeeName"),
                    property :"EmployeeName"

                },
                {
                      label : oBundle.getText("designation"),
                    property :"Designation"
                },
                {
                       label :oBundle.getText("familyMemberName"),
                    property :"MemberName"

                },
                {

                       label : oBundle.getText("relation"),
                    property :"Relationship"
                },
                  {

                       label : oBundle.getText("age"),
                    property :"Age"
                }, {

                       label :  oBundle.getText("expense"),
                    property :"ExpenseShare"
                }
            ]
            var oSettings = {
                workbook: {
                    columns: aCols,
                    context: {
                        sheetName: oBundle.getText("sheetName")
                    }
                },
                dataSource: aExportData,
                fileName: oBundle.getText("fileName"),
                worker: false
            };
            var oSpreadsheet = new Spreadsheet(oSettings);
            oSpreadsheet.build().then(function () {
                MessageToast.show(oBundle.getText("successMessage"));
            }).finally(function () {
                oSpreadsheet.destroy();
            })
        },
          
        _convertTreeForExport(aNodes, iLevel =0, aResult =[]){
// aNodes will have the tree table  data 
// iLevel -> current hierarchy depth initializes with 0
// aResult -> collector array of the flattened data 
            aNodes.forEach(oNode => {
                // taking shallow copy of each node to perform manipulations on the copy node without  // disturbing the actual data node
                   var oCopy = { ...oNode };
// deleting FamilyMembers nested structure to avoid recursion loops if not deleted it will throw  // the maximum call stack exceeded error
                delete oCopy.FamilyMembers;
                oCopy.level = iLevel + 1;
// creates a new field for visualize indentation  parent, child, grandchild etc., 
                oCopy.IndentedName = `${"".repeat(iLevel*4)}${oNode.name}`
                aResult.push(oCopy);
                if(oNode.FamilyMembers && oNode.FamilyMembers.length > 0){
                    this._convertTreeForExport(oNode.FamilyMembers, iLevel + 1, aResult);
                }
            });
               return aResult
        }

Application Screen:

 

 

ExportData.xlsx

 

 

Git Link for reference
https://github.com/RangarajasreeSV/tree-table-export-to-excel-ui5

Conclusion: 
By following these steps, We can achieve the export functionality of the The SAP UI tree table data to the Excel spreadsheet.


Thanks and Regards,
Sree Vedavyasa Rangarajasree

entry.title: Master Data Sync in Public Dimension using Hybrid Stories and Scripting in SAC
entry.content:
Introduction

Maintaining data consistency across two dimensions' attributes depending on the ID or any other attribute is a common need in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).

For instance, if one dimension (let's call it A Dimension) contains master data like product color, size, or type and another dimension (let's call it B Dimension) depends on it, then changes to a property in A Dimension must automatically be reflected in B Dimension.

Under these circumstances:

Dimension A = Dimension of the Product

B Dimension Equals Group Dimension

The objective of this approach is to use a reference key (Default_Product_ID, for instance) to synchronize the values of attributes (such Color_Code and Size_Label) between these two dimensions.

Using SAC scripting, this blog demonstrates how to synchronize properties between two dimensions in hybrid stories.

Overview of the Use case

ConceptDescription
Model UsedProduct_G_Model
Dimensions InvolvedProduct Dimension and Group Dimension
Key RelationshipEach Group member contains a property called Default_Product_ID that links it to a Product Dimension ID field
Purpose

Copy Color_Code and Size_Label from Product Dimension to Group Dimension for members flagged as “Y”

Steps involved in implementation

Step 1: Select the Planning Model

  • Choose the Planning Model.
  • Select Product_G_Model, the planning model that includes both public dimensions.

Step 2:  In the script, declare global variables.

Under Script Variables, create the following variables:

Variable NameTypeModeDescription
GroupMembersPlanningModeMemberArrayStores Group members 
ProductMembersPlanningModeMemberArrayStores Product members 
Update_PRD_KPINumberSingle
 

Tracks count of updated members

These variables make the script easier to read and reuse.

Steps 3: Write a Script Function

Create a function under Script Objects:

  • Name: updateGroupFromProducts
  • Return Type: PlanningModelMember[]
  • Arguments:
    • ProductMembers: PlanningModelMember[]
    • GroupMembers: PlanningModelMember[]

Based on Product data, this method will include the logic to change Group properties.

Step 4:  Write the Script Logic

The actual SAC script that does the synchronization is shown below:

var updatedMembers = ArrayUtils.create(Type.PlanningModelMember);
for (var j = 0; j < GroupMembers.length; j++) {
	var Member = GroupMembers[j];
	if (Member.properties.Flag === "Y") {
		for (var i = 0; i < ProductMembers.length; i++) {
			if (ProductMembers[i].id === Member.properties.Default_Product_ID) {
				Member.properties.Color_Code = ProductMembers[i].properties.Color_Code;
                Member.properties.Size_Label = ProductMembers[i].properties.Size_Label;
                updatedMembers.push(Member);
                break;
			}
		}
	}
}
return updatedMembers;

Step 5: Execute on Initialization

The script used to get members, apply updates, and refresh the model during the app's initialization is shown below:

GroupMembers=Product_G_Model.getMembers("Group_Dimension_P1",{limit:2000});
ProductMembers=Product_G_Model.getMembers("PRD_DIM_2L",{limit:200000});
 var updList=ScriptObject_1.updateGroupFromProducts(ProductMembers,GroupMembers);
	Update_PRD_KPI=updList.length;
        if (updList.length > 0) {
            var success = Product_G_Model.updateMembers("Group_Dimension_P1", updList);
            if (success) {
                Application.refreshData();
            }
        }

Sample Output

After execution, Group members flagged as "Y" will have their Color_Code and Size_Label updated based on the linked Product member.

Benefits

  • By automatically synchronizing the master data, automation removes the need for manual updates.
  • Consistently Keeps dependent dimensions conformed.
  • Reusability Function-based design allows the same logic to be applied to multiple dimensions.
  • The simplicity deploy the features and methods that are currently included in SAC scripting.

Conclusion

This method ensures data synchronization between two related dimensions within a SAC Planning Model.

Changes to dimension properties are managed while maintaining data consistency.

entry.title: Building a Lightweight Fiori-Style System Monitor with Node.js
entry.content:
Introduction

A small, lightweight tile that tells you how your server’s doing right now.  A compact Node.js app that fetches system metrics and presents them with a clean, Fiori-style interface.

To recreate this setup, you will require: 

Accounts & Platforms

  • SAP BTP Free Tier account 
  • GitHub (optional) – If you want to version your code or YAML files.

Local Tools

  • Shell or Terminal – Any terminal works (Mac Terminal, Windows PowerShell, WSL, etc.).
  • Visual Studio Code (VSC) – For editing the JS code and YAML files (not strictly necessary, but a nice to have!)

1. Setup the project

mkdir sendstats
cd sendstats
npm init -y 
npm install express

2. Create server.js

// Import modules from Node’s standard library
import express from "express";
import os from "os";
import { exec } from "child_process";

const app = express();
const PORT = process.env.PORT || 3000;

// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Serve static files from the "public" folder
// This means index.html and any JS/CSS/images in there will be delivered
// directly when requested by the browser.
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
app.use(express.static("public"));

// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// GET /stats
// This endpoint gathers system statistics (CPU, memory, uptime, disk usage)
// and returns them as JSON when the frontend calls fetch("/stats").
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
app.get("/stats", (req, res) => {
  // Run the shell command "df -h" to get human-readable disk usage
  exec("df -h", (err, stdout) => {
    // If the command failed, store an error message; otherwise, trim whitespace
    const dfOutput = err ? "Error running df" : stdout.trim();

    // Get memory information from Node’s os module
    const memTotal = os.totalmem();
    const memFree = os.freemem();
    const memUsedMb = (memTotal - memFree) / 1024 / 1024;

    // Build a data object containing all metrics we want to send to the client
    const data = {
      uptime: os.uptime(),                    // seconds since system start
      load: os.loadavg(),                     // 1-, 5-, and 15-minute load averages
      memUsedMb,                              // used memory (MB)
      memTotalMb: memTotal / 1024 / 1024,     // total memory (MB)
      memPct: ((memUsedMb / (memTotal / 1024 / 1024)) * 100).toFixed(1), // %
      cores: os.cpus().length,                // number of CPU cores
      dfOutput,                               // result of "df -h"
      timestamp: new Date().toLocaleString(), // when we collected it
    };

    // Send the JSON response back to the browser
    res.json(data);
  });
});

// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Start the Express web server
// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
app.listen(PORT, () => {
  console.log("Fiori-style monitor running at http://localhost:" + PORT);
});

So, this is now serving /stats to a front-end HTML tile that will display uptime, memory, load averages, and disk usage. 

That endpoint returns a tidy JSON snapshot, perfect for a front-end fetch call.

3. The HTML front-end

From the root of the project:

mkdir public

The folder structure (up to now) should look like this:

sendstats/

├── server.js

├── package.json

└── public/

    └── index.html

    └── script.js

Here’s the finished index.html with a working toggle switch that hides or shows the entire tile:

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8" />
    <title>System Tile</title>
    <style>
      body {
        font-family: "72","Segoe UI",sans-serif;
        background: #f4f4f4;
        display: flex;
        justify-content: center;
        align-items: center;
        height: 100vh;
        margin: 0;
        flex-direction: column;
      }
      .tile {
        background: white;
        border-radius: 1rem;
        box-shadow: 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
        padding: 1.5rem 2rem;
        width: 340px;
        text-align: left;
        transition: opacity 0.3s ease, transform 0.3s ease;
      }
      h1 {
        font-size: 1.2rem;
        color: #0a6ed1;
        margin-bottom: 0.75rem;
      }
      pre {
        font-family: monospace;
        font-size: 0.9rem;
        background: #fafafa;
        padding: 0.75rem;
        border-radius: 0.5rem;
        overflow: auto;
      }
      .footer {
        text-align: center;
        margin-top: 0.75rem;
        font-size: 0.8rem;
        color: #6a6d70;
      }
      button {
        background: #0a6ed1;
        color: white;
        border: none;
        border-radius: 0.5rem;
        padding: 0.5rem 1rem;
        cursor: pointer;
        margin-bottom: 0.5rem;
      }
      button:hover {
        background: #085caf;
      }
      .switch-container {
        display: flex;
        align-items: center;
        margin-bottom: 1rem;
      }
      .switch {
        position: relative;
        display: inline-block;
        width: 46px;
        height: 24px;
        margin-right: 0.5rem;
      }
      .switch input {
        opacity: 0;
        width: 0;
        height: 0;
      }
      .slider {
        position: absolute;
        cursor: pointer;
        top: 0;
        left: 0;
        right: 0;
        bottom: 0;
        background-color: #ccc;
        border-radius: 24px;
        transition: 0.3s;
      }
      .slider:before {
        position: absolute;
        content: "";
        height: 18px;
        width: 18px;
        left: 3px;
        bottom: 3px;
        background-color: white;
        border-radius: 50%;
        transition: 0.3s;
      }
      input:checked + .slider {
        background-color: #0a6ed1;
      }
      input:checked + .slider:before {
        transform: translateX(22px);
      }
      #toggleLabel {
        font-size: 0.8rem;
        color: #6a6d70;
      }
      .hidden {
        opacity: 0;
        transform: scale(0.95);
        pointer-events: none;
      }
    </style>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div class="switch-container">
      <label class="switch">
        <input type="checkbox" id="toggleTile" checked />
        <span class="slider"></span>
      </label>
      <span id="toggleLabel">Tile: ON</span>
    </div>

    <div class="tile" id="tile">
      <h1>System Monitor</h1>
      <button id="refresh">Refresh</button>
      <pre id="output">Loading...</pre>
      <div class="footer" id="footer"></div>
    </div>

    <script src="script.js"></script>
  </body>
</html>

4. The JavaScript logic

The script.js code below handles fetching the stats and toggling the tile’s visibility:

// script.js
async function fetchStats() {
  const res = await fetch("/stats");
  const d = await res.json();
  document.getElementById("output").textContent =
`Uptime: ${(d.uptime / 60).toFixed(2)} min
Loadavg: [${d.load.map(n => n.toFixed(2)).join(", ")}]
Memory: ${d.memUsedMb.toFixed(0)} MB / ${d.memTotalMb.toFixed(0)} MB (${d.memPct}%)
CPU cores: ${d.cores}

Disk usage (df -h):
${d.dfOutput}`;
  document.getElementById("footer").textContent =
    "Snapshot generated on " + d.timestamp;
}

document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {
  const refreshBtn = document.getElementById("refresh");
  const tile = document.getElementById("tile");
  const toggle = document.getElementById("toggleTile");
  const label = document.getElementById("toggleLabel");

  refreshBtn.addEventListener("click", fetchStats);
  fetchStats();

  toggle.addEventListener("change", (e) => {
    const visible = e.target.checked;
    label.textContent = visible ? "Tile: ON" : "Tile: OFF";
    tile.classList.toggle("hidden", !visible);
  });
});
node server

Now, when you load up localhost:3000, you should see something like this: 

You can toggle the tile on an off with the slider button: 

Off: 

5. Deploy it the Cloud Foundry

Create a manifest.yml under the root of the directory, so that the directory structure now looks like this:

sendstats/

├── server.js

├── package.json

├── manifest.yml

└── public/

    └── index.html

    └── script.js

Your manifest.yml should look something like this:

---
applications:
  - name: sendstats
    memory: 128M
    random-route: true
    command: npm start

Deploy to the Cloud Foundry with 'cf push':

cf push sendstats

You should see the following in your workspace after the app has started up: 

Click on the app name and it should take you to the 'Application Route' shown below: 

Click on the link and you should see the app: 

6. Result

When you load the app:

  • The system tile appears in the centre, showing uptime, load average, memory, CPU cores and filesystem usage.
  • The “Tile: ON/OFF” switch above it cleanly hides or shows the card with a subtle fade.
  • Everything stays minimal, modern, and in line with SAP’s Fiori look and feel.
  • You get a 'Refresh' button, which is nice!

Conclusion

This 10 minute project shows how far you can go with a few lines of JavaScript By combining a lightweight Node.js backend with a Fiori-inspired front end, we built a self-contained system monitor that’s simple, responsive, and useful.

The toggle feature gives it that final touch of polish — a reminder that usability doesn’t have to come from massive frameworks or libraries. Sometimes it’s just a matter of a few smart UI details and clean logic.

entry.title: Launch your Data Science Platform with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Let's set the architecture.

Within SAP Business Data Cloud we will use SAP Datasphere and SAP Business Data Cloud. Note that SAP Databricks runs on its own Object Store. This is not the same object store that could be activated in SAP Datasphere. We will not activate an Object Store (BDC Object Store) for this case.  You can do that. This means, that you will benefit from Data Products (SAP and Customer managed). But as of today you will lose semantics. Therefore we will go for another approach this time. Make sure to check which approach might be best for you.

 

  • 1. Step: Activate SAP Datasphere and SAP Databricks. If you already have a Datasphere (activated before 2025) and you want it to be in your BDC formation, please make sure to contact your BDC account executive.
  • 2. Step: Within SAP Datasphere create a space (HANA Cloud not Hana Data Lake Files)
  • 3. Step: Within this space, create a view which is exposed for consumption. Note that you have to create a view. Tables (also remote tables) cannot be exposed

  • 4. Step: Create a database user 

  • 5. Step Open SAP Databricks
  • 6. Step Open a Workbook and connect it to a running Cluster 
  • 7. Step Insert the following to find your Clusters IP Address
%pip install fedml-databricks --no-cache-dir --upgrade --force-reinstall from fedml_databricks import DbConnection,predict 
import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd 
import json 
import socket 

hostname = socket.gethostname() ip_address = socket.gethostbyname(hostname) display({"Cluster Hostname": hostname, "Cluster IP Address": ip_address})​
  • 8. Step: In SAP Datasphere whitelist the IP Address
  • 9. Step: Create personal token in SAP Databricks
  • 10. Step: Create Scope
  • 11. Step: Create Secret (enter Credentials from SAP Datasphere Database User)
  • 12. Step: Establish Connection with Secret
pip install hana-ml
from hana_ml.dataframe import ConnectionContext
conn = dataframe.ConnectionContext(address='',
                                   port=443, 
                                   user='', 
                                   password='' 
                                  )
conn.connection.isconnected()
  • 13. Step: Connect to view 
df_remote = hana_conn.table('<yourexposedview>', schema='<yourspaceschema>')​

Congrats! You now can perform predictions based on your data in SAP Datashere. You can return the data to SAP Datasphere as HANA Table.

entry.title: Debugging in ABAP Development Tool (Part 2)
entry.content:
Introduction 

The Blog (Part 2) provides step by step guide on how to debug the report programs, classes, Function modules and Internal tables using Eclipse ADT (ABAP Development Tool). 

Part 1 link - Debugging in ABAP Development Tool (Part 1) - SAP Community
 
In this blog, we will be covering  

  1. How to set the Dynamic Breakpoints.
  2.  How to check the type of Breakpoint set. 
  3. How to skip the set Breakpoints. 
  4. How to Insert, delete and update records of Internal table. 
  5. How to Export data from the internal table. 
  6. How to Refresh the set Breakpoints. 

Dynamic Breakpoints 

Statement Breakpoint 

Click on Add ABAP Breakpoints in Breakpoints tab as shown below 

Then click on Add Statement Breakpoint 

Then type READ E and then select the as shown and then click on ok  

Message Breakpoint 

Click on Add ABAP Breakpoint and then click on Add Message Breakpoint 

Provide the message details and then click on ok 

We can observe the breakpoint set at message 

 

Checking the type of Breakpoint set 
Click on View menu in that click on Group by and then click on Breakpoint Types 

We can observe the type of breakpoint set 

 

Skipping the set Breakpoints 

Click on Skip All Breakpoints icon in Breakpoint table 

We can observe the skip breakpoint icon on all set breakpoints 

 

Inserting, Updating and Deleting the record of Internal table in Debugging 

Inserting the data of Internal table 

Right click on record and then click on Insert Row 

Provide the values and then click on ok 

We can observe the record is appended at the last row 

Changing values of Internal table 

Right click on record and then click on Change Value 

Change the value and then click on ok 

We can observe the updated value 

Deleting the record of Internal table 

Select the record, right click on the record and then click on Delete Selected Rows 

We can observe the selected record got deleted

 

Exporting the data of Internal table 

Right click on Internal table record and then click on Export to File 

Select the number of rows to be exported, provide the path to store the file and then click on ok 

We get the popup to open the file or close the file 

 

Refreshing the set Breakpoints 

Click on Add ABAP Breakpoints in Breakpoint tab and then click on Refresh Breakpoint Activation 

 

Conclusion

Debugging internal tables in ADT offers deep visibility into runtime data, making it easier to trace logic and pinpoint issues. We can inspect table contents live, apply filters, and monitor changes using watchpoints and expressions. The structured viewer simplifies analysis of nested and dynamic data. Overall, it streamlines troubleshooting and enhances development efficiency.

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 1
entry.content:
En el mundo de los sistemas de gestión empresarial, extender una aplicación o funcionalidad estándar es crucial para adaptarse a aquellas necesidades específicas de tu negocio o para darle competitividad a tu negocio con diferenciación. SAP Cloud ERP o comúnmente llamada SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, ofrece una amplia gama de opciones que le permiten a las empresas personalizar sus sistemas sin comprometer la actualización automática (upgrade) de la plataforma. En este blog y en español 🙂,  exploraremos los tipos de extensiones disponibles en SAP Cloud ERP y cómo saber cúal y cuando usarlas. Este blog es la primera parte de una serie que pretende explicar de forma sencilla las opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP.

 

In-App Extensions

¿Qué son? Las In-App Extensions permiten personalizar aplicaciones directamente dentro del entorno de SAP Cloud ERP.  Estas extensiones son ideales para pequeños ajustes y personalizaciones que no requieren un desarrollo complejo.

Para el desarrollo de extensiones In-App tenemos dos opciones:

  • Key-user Extensibility: Estas extensiones son fáciles de crear, no requieren conocimiento complejo de programación y se hacen directamente en el sistema. Puedes crear campos personalizados, extensiones de fuentes de datos e implementar descripciones para contextos empresariales específicos, adaptando así las aplicaciones predefinidas a las necesidades de tu negocio. También puedes crear vistas personalizadas de CDS (SAP Core Data Services) basadas en fuentes de datos predefinidas, combinar datos de diferentes fuentes y reorganizar los campos de las tablas según las necesidades específicas de la aplicación.
  • Developer Extensibility: Este tipo de extensiones se crean utilizando las ADT (ABAP Development Tools), requieren de conocimiento de ABAP y actualmente premiten el uso de ABAP Cloud. La extensibilidad del desarrollador permite crear proyectos de desarrollo en SAP Cloud ERP, incluyendo la creación de servicios y aplicaciones SAP Fiori personalizados con el modelo ABAP RESTful Application Programming (RAP), utilizando un subconjunto optimizado para la nube del lenguaje ABAP y APIs/objetos liberados de SAP, con acceso controlado a herramientas administrativas y con seguridad predeterminada para tablas personalizadas.

¿Cuándo usarlas?

  • Key User Extensibility: Ideal para usuarios finales que necesitan realizar ajustes menores y personalizaciones básicas sin necesidad de codificación extensiva.
  • Developer Extensibility: Necesaria para desarrolladores que requieren crear funcionalidades completamente nuevas, realizar integraciones complejas o realizar optimizaciones avanzadas, conocimiento de ABAP es necesario

Ventajas:

  • Integración: Totalmente integradas dentro del sistema, lo que asegura una actualización sin problemas.
  • Rapidez: Permiten realizar cambios rápidamente sin necesidad de salir del entorno de SAP S/4HANA.

 

Side-by-Side Extensions

¿Qué son? Las Side-by-Side Extensions se desarrollan fuera del entorno de SAP Cloud ERP utilizando el SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), pero se integran con el sistema mediante APIs liberados. Estas extensiones son ideales para necesidades más complejas que no pueden ser cubiertas por las extenciones directamente en la solucion (Key-user y Developer Extensibility).

¿Cuándo usarlas?

  • Desarrollar aplicaciones personalizadas que complementen la funcionalidad estándar de SAP Cloud ERP.
  • Integrar con sistemas de terceros o soluciones externas.
  • Crear portales de clientes o aplicaciones móviles.
  • Aprovechar las capacidades de SAP Build
  • Desarrollar extensiones usando múltiples lenguajes de programación como ABAP, Java, JavaScript o Python.

Ventajas:

  • Flexibilidad: Permiten un mayor grado de personalización y complejidad.
  • Independencia: El desarrollo se realiza fuera del sistema, lo que facilita la gestión del ciclo de vida de la aplicación y mantenimiento.
  • Integración: Utilizan APIs estándar para conectarse con SAP Cloud ERP, lo que asegura una integración segura y eficiente.

 

Conclusión

Las opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP, son diversas, permiten adaptar la solución a las necesidades específicas de cada negocio, principalmente teniendo como ventaja, que no comprometen la estabilidad ni la capacidad de actualización del sistema. Desde In-App Extensions para cambios rápidos y sencillos, hasta Side-by-Side Extensions para necesidades más complejas y Custom Apps para soluciones altamente personalizadas, cada tipo de extensión tiene su propósito y ventajas.

Espero que esta guía te haya proporcionado una comprensión clara de las opciones de extensibilidad disponibles en SAP Cloud ERP.

¡No dudes en explorar más para descubrir cómo estas herramientas pueden ayudar a tu empresa a alcanzar nuevos niveles de eficiencia y personalización!

 

Links Relevantes:

SAP Community: La comunidad de SAP es un excelente lugar para encontrar blogs, tutoriales y discusiones sobre extensibilidad.

    • SAP Community

Documentación Oficial de SAP: La documentación oficial proporciona una guía detallada sobre cómo extender SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

    • SAP S/4HANA Cloud - Help Portal

SAP Extensibility Explorer

    • SAP Extensibility Explorer for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

SAP API Business Hub: Aquí puedes encontrar APIs, eventos y otros servicios que te permiten extender tus aplicaciones SAP.

    • SAP API Business Hub - S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP): Plataforma en la nube que incluye varios servicios para la extensibilidad.

    • SAP BTP

SAP Web IDE: Herramienta de desarrollo en la nube que facilita la extensibilidad de SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

    • SAP Web IDE

SAP Cloud SDK: Kit de desarrollo de software que facilita la integración y ampliación de soluciones SAP.

    • SAP Cloud SDK

 

📽¡Vea las repeticiones de nuestra serie de lanzamiento anticipado de SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502!  

Del 21 al 25 de julio, organizamos una serie de 21 interesantes sesiones en vivo para destacar las emocionantes innovaciones que incluye la versión 2508 de SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. ¿Te perdiste las sesiones en vivo? ¡Te ayudamos! entry.content:
Dear SAP,

When uploading data using the Market Segment Planning template in the Import Financial Plan Data app, the field value for "AccountAssignmentType" is set to blank.

The plan data distributed using the Margin Analysis cycle has the value of the "AccountAssignmentType" field set to 'EO' (Margin Analysis).

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: The field value of AccountAssignmentType in Market Se...
entry.content:
According to your upload data, there is no field to determine the EO account assignment type.

The Profit Center (PRCTR) field is organization field, which is not a factor to determine the account assignment type.

Another point is that the Import Financial Plan Data is to update planning table. The AccountAssignmentType field is different with the one in actual table.

Please refer to documentation on AccountAssignmentType field determination logic.
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1cbcff7ccd35405ab445b223c1ab1588/f40df478a24a40b197a68467cc155e82.html

entry.title: Access ODATA stream from BI Platform as Datasource in PowerBI using SSO
entry.content:
Hello,

we need to access personalized Webi Report content as a datasource in PowerBI. Personalization is the key here, as the data is personalized so every PowerBI user integrating this report data only has access to its own dataset. this personalization is implemented already in the underlying database, so no way to maniulate that in the webi report itself.

As we understood, the only suitable way to have a realtime access is using ODATA export from the BI Platform and PowerBI connects using a ODATA datasource.

This architecture would work, if we could use a BO enterprise (service) user, but with respect to the data personalization this is not working for our demand of having a clear user mapping between PowerBI and the BI Platform. That said, we need to establish a user mapping including SSO to the BI Platform.

Unfortunately this is not supported from PowerBI, because technically the logon process is a separate webservice invocation that generates the logon token, that needs to be added in the HTTP headers of the ODATA request. And here we wonder, if there is a way to do that in an automated way, so that users don"t have to do these steps as they simply cannot (and will not accept that anyway).

So my question is, what are the experiences and potential solutions found for this use case? Is there a prefferable middleware (CData?) that would help us to implement the described scenario?

Technical architecture:

  • BI2025, using WinAD SSO authentication on Windows 2025
  • PowerBI from MS365

Thank you!

Regards Bernhard

entry.title: SAP Ariba Category Management 2511 Release Highlights
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community and welcome to this latest blog post on the exciting updates coming to SAP Ariba Category Management in the Q4 2025 release! We are thrilled to introduce features that are designed to enhance your efficiency, streamline workflows, and deliver actionable insights for your category management strategies. Let's dive into the key updates that will help you drive even greater business value.

 

1.  Use of Spend Data for AI Recommendations in Category Segmentation (ARBCATA-504)

In this release, we are leveraging your organization's spend data to generate AI-based insights within the Category Segmentation tool. By integrating additional spend attributes, the segmentation results will now more accurately reflect actual spending patterns. This not only minimizes manual effort but also accelerates the development of your category strategies. The AI engine analyzes both your organization's total spend and category-level spend data, delivering faster, more accurate segmentation.

 

When you generate AI-based category segmentation recommendations, the SAP Business AI link now shows Spend as a new option, along with two new input parameters in the Spend Data section. The link shows the following new input parameters - Category's total spend and Organization's total spend

 

2.  Email and In-App Notifications for SAP Ariba Category Management (CATMAN-118)

Staying informed and acting promptly on critical activities becomes easier with our new configurable email and in-app notifications. You will now receive alerts for key events such as being assigned as a team member for a category, becoming the owner of an initiative, or when a strategy and plan document needs to be updated. Approval-related emails have also been enhanced, incorporating direct links that enable approvers to quickly access their assigned documents in My Inbox, and submitters to directly open the approved or rejected strategies in Develop Strategy and Plan. By effectively managing notifications, teams can ensure greater alignment, accountability, and efficiency in executing your category strategies.

A new Notifications option is now available under the General Settings dropdown menu

 

The Notifications page provides toggles for three notification scenarios, which you can enable based on your organization requirements.

 

3. Enhancements to the Develop Strategy and Plan Page (ARBCATA-334)

We've added filtering capabilities to the Develop Strategy and Plan page, allowing you to customize your view for optimal efficiency. The new Adapt Filters button lets you choose which filters are displayed, ensuring only the most relevant criteria are visible. These enhancements help category managers quickly access and manage strategy and plan documents, streamlining workflows and boosting productivity.

Sample of the Develop Strategy and Plan page with the new filters

 

4. Ability to Add Collaborators to a Strategy and Plan Document (ARBCATA-31)

This release introduces the capability to add team members maintained in the Manage Category Profile app as collaborators to your strategy and plan documents. Collaborators can create and manage their own initiatives, promoting effective and collaborative strategy development while ensuring clear ownership and accountability. Category strategy and plan owners or lead category managers can assign multiple collaborators to support coordinated execution and contribute to the overall strategy. Additionally, the Assignee field has been replaced with a new Owner field on all applicable pages, including the initiatives page.

the new Add Collaborators option in the strategy and plan header

the new Add Collaborators dialog box

 

5.  Ability to Use the External Factors Analysis Tool in Category Management (CATMAN-446)

We are excited to introduce the External Factors Analysis Tool, which allows you to model variations of the PESTLE framework within your strategy and plan documents. The PESTLE framework is a strategic method for analyzing key external influences and macro-economic factors that may impact your category. By leveraging this tool, category managers can better understand how external dynamics could affect their strategies and sourcing decisions, enabling them to identify risks and opportunities early, and make more informed, proactive planning choices aligned with broader business objectives.

A new option, External Factors, in now available under the Strategy and Plan dropdown menu

 

6.  Ability to Create and Use Custom Entities in Custom Strategy and Plan Tools (ARBCATA-334)

This feature enables you to:

- Use the Extensibility Portal app to create custom entities and define custom fields for these entities in SAP Ariba Category Management.

- Configure the custom strategy and plan tool to include the custom entities created in the extensibility portal in the Develop Strategy and Plan app.

- Leverage the adapt UI functionality to personalize the custom strategy and plan tool layout in the Develop Strategy and Plan app.

These enhancements allow you to gather organization-specific data effectively for specific business processes and reporting needs, ensuring a more tailored and efficient strategy development process.

the new Custom Component option

These updates are designed to empower your category management teams with the tools they need to stay ahead in a dynamic market. Stay tuned for more enhancements and continue to leverage SAP Ariba Category Management to drive business success!

As always, thank you for being part of the SAP Ariba community. We look forward to supporting your journey in delivering exceptional category management strategies.

 

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link and for CIM customers- P2P link  (Thanks Natalie!)
  • Resources:
    • Feature related materials
      • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
      • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
    • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
    • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
    • What’s New

entry.content:
Hi Ashish,

Sometimes, trial systems experience loading issues due to high usage—many users share the same instance and create numerous services. For example, this issue has been reported: Can't link my IAM Travel App to a published OData service

As a workaround, try copying and pasting the exact service name from the tutorial into BAS instead of relying on autocomplete. If that doesn’t help, you can connect to your trial instance using ADT and check whether a service binding with that name exists.

If the service binding is missing, you can generate your own UI service by following this guide: Create Database Table and Generate UI Service.

Best regards,
Peter

entry.title: Re: RFQ Comparison
entry.content:
Hi,

Please see the content in Compare Supplier Quotations

With this app, you can Compare up to three supplier quotations

Also according to the KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003411976

It is not possible to add additional fields in Compare supplier quotation App.

The App Compare Supplier Quotation uses service- MM_PUR_QTN_COMPARE_SRV in the backend. CDS views C_RequestForQuotationCompare, C_SupplierQuotationCompare used for this service does not support metadata extension. 

This app has no extensibility available.

Add the zero net price is not supported for quote submission in the standard system.

Consider raising a feature request.

1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

2. Register and accept the Terms of Use

3. Choose a session of your interest

4. Create and submit your improvement request

5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thanks and regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Automatically plan production order after component a...
entry.content:
Hello @Jakobstrom 

I don't think you can do that automatically. Of course, you can use MRP exceptions and quickly identify supply/demand misalignments and act accordingly. However, those actions or remedies have to be done manually. The reason is that each time a human decision is needed.

What you are looking for is essentially putting MRP planning on its head. MRP tells you what you need to produce/purchase not what you can produce/purchase. MRP is demand driven. It looks at demand and builds a supply plan. It works top-down. It doesn't work bottom-up. It doesn't look at your components and tell you what you can produce with that. If you went bottom-up, you would end up with products that can be produced but that might not be needed in the first place. That is not the way to manage inventory.

Honestly, that is not the first time I hear this question. To me it is a telltale sign that the supply chain planning / management / integration is broken.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2510 – What’s New?
entry.content:
The latest October release for SAP Business Network for Logistics brings several updates in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration aimed at refining the user experience and improving operational efficiency. With a focus on restructuring existing tools, enhancing usability, and providing better visibility into key processes, these changes address evolving needs in logistics and freight management.

In this blog post, we’ll provide an overview of the newly introduced features, ranging from improvements in dock appointment scheduling and dispute management to updates to application help and API documentation. Let’s take a closer look at what this release has to offer.

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Application Help in SAP Help Portal has been restructured

In the application help on SAP Help Portal, the sequence of topics has changed to create a more natural order.

 

2026 Release schedule in out

The release schedule for 2026 is now available on the product page on SAP Help Portal.

 

Provider API for Order Events (FC): GEOLOC event type has been deprecated

In the ‘Provider API for Order Events (FC)’, the GEOLOC event type has been deprecated in the freight collaboration component.

 

API documentation now available in HTML version

The new API Documentation is now available in the HTML version on the product page. It consolidates content on public APIs and GTT backend service interfaces that were previously scattered across two guides.

 

‘Manage Integration Logs’ app: search on document ID (without requiring a timestamp) enabled

The ‘Manage Integration Logs’ app now allows users to search by document ID without requiring a timestamp. The ‘Received On’ filter has become optional.

Users now have the following search options:

  • Search by Document ID
  • Search by Received On
  • Search by Document ID and Received On

 

Cancellation of freight documents in external system

When the ordering party cancels a freight document in its external system that has been sent for confirmation to the carrier, the corresponding freight order is cancelled in the ‘Freight Orders for Confirmation’ app and the ‘Invoice Freight Documents’ app.

Note that the freight order can be cancelled only when there is no active dispute or corresponding invoice document.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: new carrier filter and enhanced sorting

In the main view of the ‘Manage Gate Operations’ app, we introduced a new carrier filter, allowing users to streamline their workflow by focusing on specific carriers. Enhanced table sorting and grouping options provide greater flexibility in personalizing data presentation, improving efficiency and user experience.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: new event status filter

In the table view of the ‘Manage Dock Appointments’ app, we introduced a new event status filter, allowing users to easily sort and manage appointments based on their status. This enhancement improves efficiency by providing a streamlined way to access and organize appointment information.

 

Settlement: ‘Invoice Freight Documents’ app: now showing document status ‘Uploaded’ and ‘Cancelled’

In the ‘Invoice Freight Documents’ app, in the worklist page, you can now view the document statuses ‘Updated’ and ‘Cancelled’ as a label in the worklist. When the ordering party updates a freight document in their external system, you can view the ‘Updated’ label for the freight document in the worklist. When the ordering party cancels a freight document in their external system, you can view the ‘Cancelled’ label for the freight document in the worklist.

 The labels also show on the detail pages of the freight document.

 

Settlement: ‘Manage Disputes’: new status introduced ‘In Error’

In the ‘Manage Disputes’ app, a new dispute status ‘In Error’ has been added. (see below).

 

Settlement: ‘Manage Disputes’ app: new tab ‘Error Logs’

An ‘Error’ message in the ‘Error Logs’ tab in the ‘Manage Disputes’ app indicates that there was a failure in the update of agreed charges in the external system. Shippers will thus know, in case charges have not been updated.

Additional details can be found in the error message detail view.

 

---------------------

The above summarizes the key innovations for 2510. We hope you enjoy the new capabilities. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2510 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: Restrict User from creating back date invoice for spe...
entry.content:
Hello @aakash96 

If your goal is to prevent users from creating invoices until checks or approvals are finished, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud offers standard options. It is recommended to implement the following.

Preliminary Billing and Workflow (recommended)

Allow users to create only Preliminary Billing Documents app

Configure approval workflow with app Manage Preliminary Billing Document Workflows.

Remove the Create Billing Documents App from end-user roles to ensure that only approved preliminary documents can be converted into final invoices.

Billing Block or Incompletion to implement Process Control

Set a default billing block on order or delivery types, releasing it after review.

Keep Incompletion Procedures active to prevent invoice generation until all required data, like FACe/DIR3, is completed.

Role Restriction (hard stop)

Restrict access to the invoice creation app, Create Billing Documents, to a small group of authorised users only.

Recommendation:
Use Preliminary Billing along with Workflow to ensure proper approval tracking and, optionally, combine it with billing blocks or incompletion steps to enforce data quality before invoicing.

With kind regards

Chuma

Environment : SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

The field LIKP-ITM_KZABE (Id Means of Transport Inland)  is not in the element list of the CDS Entity I_DELIVERYDOCUMENT.

How can one extract that field in ABAP Cloud ?

entry.title: Why Devtoberfest keeps me coming back
entry.content:
Hello world, and happy Devtoberfest!

Since 2022, I’ve been taking part in SAP Devtoberfest. What started out as a fun experiment has quickly turned into a tradition that I look forward to each year.

Devtoberfest is much more than collecting points or badges. It’s about learning in a playful way, exploring new aspects of the SAP ecosystem, and feeling the great energy of the SAP Community. Each task, whether challenging or simple, brings something new. Sometimes a smile, sometimes an “aha” moment that finds its way into my daily work. The 2025 Devtoberfest is still running, and once again it has already given me many of those moments.

A personal highlight for me was being one of the winners in 2023. The prize trip took place in November 2024 and included the chance to attend ASUG TechConnect in West Palm Beach and to visit Disney World in Orlando together with the other winners and the SAP Developer Advocates. The time we spent together was inspiring and made the community spirit come alive.

None of this would be possible without the dedicated work of the SAP Developer Advocates and everyone supporting them behind the scenes. You create an event that connects developers around the world, motivates them, and makes learning fun. For that, I want to say a heartfelt thank you.

👉What about you? What has been your favorite Devtoberfest moment so far?

I’d love to hear how you are experiencing this year’s journey.

Best regards,
Sebastian
